name: Feminists for Reproductive Equity & Education
description:
Feminists for Reproductive Equity and Education (F.R.E.E.) (previously known as Aggies for Reproductive Justice and Pro-Choice Aggies) is a student activist organization whose main focus is fighting for a social justice movement rooted in the belief that individuals and communities should have the resources and power to make sustainable and liberating decisions about their bodies, genders, sexualities, and lives. This movement is called the Reproductive Justice movement.

We have been hosting consent workshops since August 2015. To request a consent workshop for your student or Greek organization, click the 'Got Consent?' button on our website or email us at freeaggies@gmail.com. We take requests at any time!

We are a safe(r) space organization. For anyone attending a meeting, we have safe space contracts to keep everyone's personal stories personal and private so that everyone attending a meeting understands the type of environment we are creating. We are always accepting new members; dues are $15 for the year or $10 per semester.

 

WEBSITES

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/freeaggies

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FREE_Aggies | @FREE_Aggies

Website: freeaggies.wix.com/free-aggies

 

 

NEWS ARTICLES (featuring PCA/A4RJ/F.R.E.E.)

  • U.S. Women get creative fighting abortion stigma (2016)
  • Guest Column: We must be unapologetic in demanding safe abortion (2016)
  • Texans Honor Roe Anniversary with Promise to Fight Back (2016) [Note: We’re incorrectly identified as the El Paso chapter]
  • Event to cover broad spectrum of human rights (2015)
  • A&M redefines sexual consent in conduct code to be clearer (2015)
  • WORDS WITHOUT CLEAR MEANING Today’s euphemisms may cause uncertainty on sexual consent (2015)
  • RED LIGHT, GREEN LIGHT Seminar looks to cut through euphemisms, define consent (2015)
  • Group undertakes Northgate condom crawl to better sex education (2015)

  • Time to talk: Monologues to explore sexuality, identity (2014)

  • Unruly Mob Protest Against HB2 in Austin (2014) [Update: On June 27, 2016, the Supreme Court struck down HB2, Texas' medically unnecessary anti-choice legislation]

FAQs

What is Reproductive Justice?

·Simple answer: It’s a movement that supports people’s right to make informed, healthy decisions regarding their bodies and sexual health. It’s the right to feel safe no matter what decisions you make for your own body.


·Complex answer: It’s a social and political movement that combines social justice and reproductive rights. Reproductive Justice aims to provide all people with the economic, social, and political power and resources to make healthy and informed decisions about their own bodies, body expression, sexuality, and reproduction.

 

What is intersectionality?

·Simple answer: It’s the idea that all people are connected and no one lives a single-issue life. It’s the idea that we are stronger united.


·Complex answer: It describe the interconnectedness and overlap of social structures such as class, race, gender and more which perpetuate the systems of discrimination and oppression around the world. Our group takes an intersectional approach to justice, because the only way we can truly make change is to be united. New work in the Reproductive Justice movement is also including post-colonial activism.

 

What does F.R.E.E. do?

·We are an educational organization that focuses on the intersectionality of reproductive justice through events such as bimonthly meetings, tabling events, condom crawls, and various other activities. We also put on events such as The Vagina Monologues and Out of Silence: Abortion Stories from the 1 in 3 Campaign.

·We are not a debate club. Any requests for such an event will be declined. We are also not a political organization. We believe that Reproductive Justice should not be a political issue; RJ is a right that anyone should have access to.

 

What does it mean to be pro-choice?

·Simple answer: It means that we believe that every person should have the legal and social right and ability to access to the entire spectrum of choices about how to best approach their pregnancy. It also means we believe that the only person who can make the right decision about how to approach their pregnancy is the pregnant individual.

·Complex answer: It means that we believe that every person should have the legal and social right and ability to access to the entire spectrum of choices about how to best approach their pregnancy.

This includes the right to access and have complete, unbiased information about all possible choices regarding a pregnancy; possible choices include the right to prenatal care and postnatal care, to continue a pregnancy and become a parent, to end a pregnancy through abortion, to continue a pregnancy and give the child up for adoption, or to choose surrogacy. People should have the right to access medical care if they experience a miscarriage, the post baby blues, postpartum psychosis, etc. We believe that people should not be criminalized for the path they individually choose to take.

Our personal beliefs (our members' beliefs) about abortion, adoption, prenatal care, postnatal care, and surrogacy should only apply to our own lives.

It is entirely possible to not consider abortion as a possible choice for yourself and to be pro-choice. This is because being pro-choice is believing that the choice of how to approach a pregnancy can only be determined by the individual who is pregnant and anyone who the pregnant individual voluntarily chooses to involve.

 

What is a Condom Crawl? 

·Members and volunteers distribute condoms and Northgate after members of the organization prepare condoms that have been donated to us by The Great American Condom Campaign, Planned Parenthood, and Unite for Reproductive & Gender Equity (URGE) by taping (not stapling) coupons, our contact information, or fun facts to them and putting them in bags.

 

What are The Vagina Monologues?

·The Vagina Monologues is a play created by Eve Ensler made up of monologues which address taboo topics about vaginas. The topics addressed range from funny topics to more serious topics including lack of consent. This play is not intended to define what a woman is or a what a person with a vagina is. It is simply a play about the personal experiences of different people who have a vagina. (The play has a specific set of monologues.)

 

What is Out of Silence: Stories from the 1 in 3 Campaign?

·The 1 in 3 Campaign is an abortion positive campaign which uses the statistic that 1 in 3 people will have an abortion in their lifetime. Out of Silence is a play that showcases some of the thousands of shared abortion stories given to the campaign. We encourage more before to #ShoutYourAbortion to help build community and de-stigmatize abortion.
summary: Feminists for Reproductive Equity & Education (F.R.E.E.) is a non-partisan student activist group at TAMU fighting for the Reproductive Justice (RJ) movement. Join us today to make RJ a reality in our community and beyond!
